G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as Defendant resides and conducts business in this Commonwealth and the events giving rise to this action occurred within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 5.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lynn District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 5, as the events at issue occurred at 123 Maple Street, Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26F.proposition: Defendant’s duty to maintain functional smoke detectors is mandated by Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 148, § 26F, which requires installation and maintenance of smoke alarms in residential buildings.

*Haddad v. First Nat'l Stores*, 295 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw establishes that landlords may be held liable for injuries resulting from their failures to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Haddad v. First Nat'l Stores*, 295 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns municipal finance law and the authority of a city licensing board to incur liabilities without prior appropriation. It does not involve landlord-tenant relationships, statutory safety measures, or liability for personal injuries. The holding is that the board’s contract for legal services was invalid for lack of appropriation, which is unrelated to the proposed rule about landlord liability for failures to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Haddad v. First Nat'l Stores*, 295 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “It is plain from the provisions of the city charter of the defendant that the local licensing board had no power to make expenditures beyond the appropriations previously voted. Therefore any indebtedness incurred by the licensing board in excess of its appropriation was illegal and void. It follows that the local licensing board had no authority to employ counsel in the proceedings in question since no appropriation had been previously made for it.”

*Lindberg v. Huntley*, 338 Mass. 78, 84.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw establishes that landlords may be held liable for injuries resulting from their failures to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Lindberg v. Huntley*, 338 Mass. 78, 84.support_reasoning: This case concerns an agency/brokerage-style contract for the sale of real estate and the defendant’s contractual duty to account for sale proceeds. It does not involve landlord-tenant relations, statutory safety measures, or tort liability for injuries. The holding is about breach of contract and measure of damages, so it does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts landlords may be held liable for injuries arising from failure to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Lindberg v. Huntley*, 338 Mass. 78, 84.relevant_excerpt: "Upon the agreed facts, although the defendant committed no breach of the sale agreement (as we have construed it) in selling the real estate partly for credit and partly for cash, he did clearly commit a breach of contract by refusing to account to the plaintiff for all the proceeds of the sale. He was bound by his contract to pay or transfer to the plaintiff the proceeds in excess of his commission and expenses and the encumbrances."

*Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.raw_text: *Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.*, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 453, 455 (2006)
*Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.proposition: Massachusetts caselaw establishes that landlords may be held liable for injuries resulting from their failures to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.case_name: Petrillo v. Zoning Board of Appeals
*Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning, lot combination across municipal boundaries, and res judicata in the context of zoning board decisions. It does not involve landlord–tenant relationships, statutory safety measures, or landlord liability for injuries. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that Massachusetts landlords may be held liable for injuries arising from failures to maintain statutory safety measures.
*Andre v. Springfield Redevelopment Auth.relevant_excerpt: The case focuses on whether parcels in different towns can be combined to satisfy zoning lot-size requirements and on the preclusive effect of an earlier zoning board decision. There is no discussion of landlord liability, tenant injuries, or statutory safety measures.

*Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*.raw_text: *Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*, 329 Mass. 278, 280 (1952)
*Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions further constituted negligence per se, as Defendant failed to comply with Massachusetts fire safety statutes, including G.L. c. 148, § 26F.
*Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*.case_name: Massachusetts Bonding & Insurance v. Commissioner of Insurance
*Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns judicial review of the Massachusetts commissioner of insurance’s setting of compulsory motor vehicle liability insurance premium rates. It does not involve fire safety, G.L. c. 148, § 26F, negligence per se, or any tort liability analysis. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to comply with Massachusetts fire safety statutes constitutes negligence per se.
*Berlinsky v. Alpen Glow Ski Shop, Inc.*.relevant_excerpt: The pertinent provisions of § 113B are: “The commissioner shall, . . . after due hearing and investigation, fix and establish fair and reasonable classifications of risks and adequate, just, reasonable and non-discriminatory premium charges to be used and charged by companies in connection with the issue or execution of motor vehicle liability policies or bonds ....”
